Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "<script>alert('xss')</script>".

results.description: The GraphQL error response reflects the exact user-supplied input containing a <script> tag back in the JSON error message. This is a reflected HTML/script payload present in server output. If a client (for example a web UI) renders error messages into a page without proper escaping/encoding, the injected script could execute in users' browsers (reflected XSS). The server should avoid echoing raw user input in error messages or must ensure all such output is properly escaped/sanitized before rendering. Recommended fixes: do not include raw input in errors, encode/escape error text in clients, validate/sanitize inputs server-side, and adopt a safe error formatting policy that omits or neutralizes user-controlled content.

llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error response reflects the exact user-supplied input containing a <script> tag back in the JSON error message. This is a reflected HTML/script payload present in server output. If a client (for example a web UI) renders error messages into a page without proper escaping/encoding, the injected script could execute in users' browsers (reflected XSS). The server should avoid echoing raw user input in error messages or must ensure all such output is properly escaped/sanitized before rendering. Recommended fixes: do not include raw input in errors, encode/escape error text in clients, validate/sanitize inputs server-side, and adopt a safe error formatting policy that omits or neutralizes user-controlled content.

results.description: The GraphQL error message reflects the exact user-supplied input including raw HTML tags (<div> and <b>) back in the response. This shows the server is returning unescaped HTML content in error strings. If a client (web application or admin UI) inserts these error messages into a webpage without proper escaping or sanitization, an attacker could supply crafted HTML (or script tags) and trigger reflected HTML injection / XSS in the victim's browser. The presence of HTML in the response is direct evidence of an HTML injection risk; the exploitability depends on how client code renders these messages, but the returned response makes exploitation feasible. Recommend treating all user input as untrusted, escape or sanitize values before including them in HTML, and avoid reflecting raw input in error messages.

\"."
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error message reflects the exact user-supplied input including raw HTML tags (<div> and <b>) back in the response. This shows the server is returning unescaped HTML content in error strings. If a client (web application or admin UI) inserts these error messages into a webpage without proper escaping or sanitization, an attacker could supply crafted HTML (or script tags) and trigger reflected HTML injection / XSS in the victim's browser. The presence of HTML in the response is direct evidence of an HTML injection risk; the exploitability depends on how client code renders these messages, but the returned response makes exploitation feasible. Recommend treating all user input as untrusted, escape or sanitize values before including them in HTML, and avoid reflecting raw input in error messages.

errors.message: Cannot query field "types" on type "PhotosPage".
Field "page" is not defined by type "PageQueryOptions".
Field "limit" is not defined by type "PageQueryOptions".
Cannot query field "titel" on type "Photo". Did you mean "title"?
Cannot query field "thumnailUrl" on type "Photo". Did you mean "thumbnailUrl"?

results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure
results.evidence: Found "did you mean" in error message - field suggestions are enabled

results.description: The GraphQL error responses explicitly suggest correct field names and reveal type names (e.g., Photo, PageQueryOptions). The "Did you mean ...?" suggestions are a field_suggestions information-disclosure issue because they allow an attacker to infer valid field names and parts of the schema without proper introspection, aiding schema enumeration and targeted probing. This is primarily an information disclosure risk (low severity in isolation) rather than an injection or command execution vulnerability. Mitigation: disable or sanitize suggestion messages, avoid returning detailed schema/type names in production errors, and return generic validation errors instead.
results.evidence: Error messages: "Cannot query field \"titel\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"title\"?" and "Cannot query field \"thumnailUrl\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"thumbnailUrl\"?". Additional schema exposure: "Field \"page\" is not defined by type \"PageQueryOptions\"."

llm_analysis.evidence: Error messages: "Cannot query field \"titel\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"title\"?" and "Cannot query field \"thumnailUrl\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"thumbnailUrl\"?". Additional schema exposure: "Field \"page\" is not defined by type \"PageQueryOptions\"."
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error responses explicitly suggest correct field names and reveal type names (e.g., Photo, PageQueryOptions). The "Did you mean ...?" suggestions are a field_suggestions information-disclosure issue because they allow an attacker to infer valid field names and parts of the schema without proper introspection, aiding schema enumeration and targeted probing. This is primarily an information disclosure risk (low severity in isolation) rather than an injection or command execution vulnerability. Mitigation: disable or sanitize suggestion messages, avoid returning detailed schema/type names in production errors, and return generic validation errors instead.

errors.message: Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "1' OR '1'='1".
Field "limit" is not defined by type "PageQueryOptions".
Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "<script>alert(document.domain)</script>".
Field "limit" is not defined by type "PageQueryOptions".

results.description: The GraphQL response is reflecting user-supplied input containing a <script> tag verbatim inside the error message. Specifically the payload "<script>alert(document.domain)</script>" appears in the JSON error text. If a client application (web frontend) takes these error messages and injects them into the DOM without proper escaping or sanitization, the reflected script will execute in users' browsers (reflected XSS). The presence of the raw script in the response is a reliable indicator of possible reflected XSS risk; whether it is exploitable depends on how/if the client renders this error text into HTML. Recommended fixes: do not include raw user input in HTML contexts, ensure server escapes or removes HTML/script characters in error messages, and have the frontend treat server responses as untrusted and safely encode/escape before inserting into the DOM.
results.evidence: "Expected value of type \"SearchOptions\", found \"<script>alert(document.domain)</script>\"." (reflected script tag in GraphQL error message)

llm_analysis.evidence: "Expected value of type \"SearchOptions\", found \"<script>alert(document.domain)</script>\"." (reflected script tag in GraphQL error message)
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL response is reflecting user-supplied input containing a <script> tag verbatim inside the error message. Specifically the payload "<script>alert(document.domain)</script>" appears in the JSON error text. If a client application (web frontend) takes these error messages and injects them into the DOM without proper escaping or sanitization, the reflected script will execute in users' browsers (reflected XSS). The presence of the raw script in the response is a reliable indicator of possible reflected XSS risk; whether it is exploitable depends on how/if the client renders this error text into HTML. Recommended fixes: do not include raw user input in HTML contexts, ensure server escapes or removes HTML/script characters in error messages, and have the frontend treat server responses as untrusted and safely encode/escape before inserting into the DOM.

results.detection_name: LLM: GraphQL schema disclosure (introspection via error messages)
results.description: The GraphQL responses expose type and field names in validation errors (e.g., PhotosPage, PageQueryOptions, Query.photos and their arguments). Although this is not an explicit __schema introspection query result, it leaks schema structure and allowed/unsupported fields/arguments to unauthenticated clients. This disclosure can be used to map the API schema and craft targeted queries or attacks. Recommendation: avoid exposing detailed schema information in error messages (return generic errors), restrict or disable introspection in production where appropriate, and enforce authentication/authorization for schema-sensitive endpoints.
results.evidence: Error messages reveal internal schema names and details: "Unknown argument \"name\" on field \"Query.photos\".", "Cannot query field \"name\" on type \"PhotosPage\".", "Field \"page\" is not defined by type \"PageQueryOptions\"."

llm_analysis.vulnerability_type: GraphQL schema disclosure (introspection via error messages)
llm_analysis.evidence: Error messages reveal internal schema names and details: "Unknown argument \"name\" on field \"Query.photos\".", "Cannot query field \"name\" on type \"PhotosPage\".", "Field \"page\" is not defined by type \"PageQueryOptions\"."
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL responses expose type and field names in validation errors (e.g., PhotosPage, PageQueryOptions, Query.photos and their arguments). Although this is not an explicit __schema introspection query result, it leaks schema structure and allowed/unsupported fields/arguments to unauthenticated clients. This disclosure can be used to map the API schema and craft targeted queries or attacks. Recommendation: avoid exposing detailed schema information in error messages (return generic errors), restrict or disable introspection in production where appropriate, and enforce authentication/authorization for schema-sensitive endpoints.

results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure
results.evidence: Found "did you mean" in error message - field suggestions are enabled

results.description: The GraphQL error responses include automatic field name suggestions (e.g., "Did you mean \"title\"?" and "Did you mean \"url\"?"). This behavior discloses valid schema information (field names and types) to an unauthenticated requester, enabling schema/field enumeration which can aid further targeted attacks or discovery of sensitive data. To mitigate, return generic validation errors without suggested field names, disable or limit auto-suggestions, or restrict schema introspection and error detail in production.
results.evidence: "Cannot query field \"titl\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"title\"?" and "Cannot query field \"ur\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"url\"?"

llm_analysis.evidence: "Cannot query field \"titl\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"title\"?" and "Cannot query field \"ur\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"url\"?"
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error responses include automatic field name suggestions (e.g., "Did you mean \"title\"?" and "Did you mean \"url\"?"). This behavior discloses valid schema information (field names and types) to an unauthenticated requester, enabling schema/field enumeration which can aid further targeted attacks or discovery of sensitive data. To mitigate, return generic validation errors without suggested field names, disable or limit auto-suggestions, or restrict schema introspection and error detail in production.

results.description: The GraphQL error message echoes the raw input containing a <script> tag back in the JSON response: the server returns "Expected value of type \"SearchOptions\", found \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"." This indicates user-supplied markup is reflected without escaping. If a web client or admin UI renders these error messages into a page without proper HTML-escaping or sanitization, the reflected script could execute in a victim's browser (reflected XSS). The response being JSON does not itself execute script, but the unescaped inclusion of script tags in an error message is a clear XSS vector when error text is inserted into HTML. Recommend treating as a reflected XSS risk: sanitize/encode user input in error messages, avoid echoing raw input, and use context-appropriate escaping on any client that renders these messages.

If a web client or admin UI renders these error messages into a page without proper HTML-escaping or sanitization, the reflected script could execute in a victim's browser (reflected XSS). The response being JSON does not itself execute script, but the unescaped inclusion of script tags in an error message is a clear XSS vector when error text is inserted into HTML. Recommend treating as a reflected XSS risk: sanitize/encode user input in error messages, avoid echoing raw input, and use context-appropriate escaping on any client that renders these messages.

click
".

results.description:
The GraphQL error response reflects the exact user-supplied HTML string (
click
) inside the validation message. This is clear evidence of HTML being echoed back by the API. While the response is JSON (so execution is not immediate), any client or UI that renders these error messages into HTML pages without proper escaping would allow the injected markup (and its event handler) to execute, resulting in a reflected HTML/DOM injection and potential XSS. This is a server-side reflection of untrusted input; to remediate, ensure the server does not include raw HTML in responses or properly escape/encode error text, and validate/sanitize inputs before including them in messages. Also review client UI handling of server error text to ensure safe rendering.

While the response is JSON (so execution is not immediate), any client or UI that renders these error messages into HTML pages without proper escaping would allow the injected markup (and its event handler) to execute, resulting in a reflected HTML/DOM injection and potential XSS. This is a server-side reflection of untrusted input; to remediate, ensure the server does not include raw HTML in responses or properly escape/encode error text, and validate/sanitize inputs before including them in messages. Also review client UI handling of server error text to ensure safe rendering.

results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure
results.evidence: Found "did you mean" in error message - field suggestions are enabled

results.description: The GraphQL response returns field-suggestion style errors that reveal schema details. The explicit "Did you mean \"title\"?" message discloses a valid field name on the Photo type, and the other errors reveal type and field names (PageQueryOptions, page, limit). This information disclosure aids an attacker in enumerating the GraphQL schema and crafting targeted queries. Recommend disabling or sanitizing developer-style suggestion messages in production (return generic validation errors), and restrict schema introspection or apply strict error handling/logging to avoid leaking schema details.
results.evidence: Error message: "Cannot query field \"titl\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"title\"?"; other errors revealing type/field names: "Field \"page\" is not defined by type \"PageQueryOptions\"." and "Field \"limit\" is not defined by type \"PageQueryOptions\"."

llm_analysis.evidence: Error message: "Cannot query field \"titl\" on type \"Photo\". Did you mean \"title\"?"; other errors revealing type/field names: "Field \"page\" is not defined by type \"PageQueryOptions\"." and "Field \"limit\" is not defined by type \"PageQueryOptions\"."
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL response returns field-suggestion style errors that reveal schema details. The explicit "Did you mean \"title\"?" message discloses a valid field name on the Photo type, and the other errors reveal type and field names (PageQueryOptions, page, limit). This information disclosure aids an attacker in enumerating the GraphQL schema and crafting targeted queries. Recommend disabling or sanitizing developer-style suggestion messages in production (return generic validation errors), and restrict schema introspection or apply strict error handling/logging to avoid leaking schema details.

errors.message: Field "filter" is not defined by type "PageQueryOptions".
Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "<script>alert('xss')</script>".

results.description: The GraphQL response reflects unescaped user-supplied input (the <script>alert('xss')</script> string) back in an error message. While this is a validation error (400) and appears to be reflected rather than stored, returning raw HTML/script content in API responses creates a reflected XSS risk if any client (web application, admin UI, or developer tooling) injects that error text into a web page DOM without proper encoding/escaping. This is clear evidence of potential reflected XSS. Mitigations include: avoid reflecting raw input in error messages, HTML-encode/escape any user data before inserting into web pages, validate and reject dangerous input server-side, and restrict error output shown to end users (log full details server-side only).
results.evidence: GraphQL error message contains the raw input: "Expected value of type \"SearchOptions\", found \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"."

llm_analysis.evidence: GraphQL error message contains the raw input: "Expected value of type \"SearchOptions\", found \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"."
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL response reflects unescaped user-supplied input (the <script>alert('xss')</script> string) back in an error message. While this is a validation error (400) and appears to be reflected rather than stored, returning raw HTML/script content in API responses creates a reflected XSS risk if any client (web application, admin UI, or developer tooling) injects that error text into a web page DOM without proper encoding/escaping. This is clear evidence of potential reflected XSS. Mitigations include: avoid reflecting raw input in error messages, HTML-encode/escape any user data before inserting into web pages, validate and reject dangerous input server-side, and restrict error output shown to end users (log full details server-side only).

results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure
results.evidence: Found "did you mean" in error message - field suggestions are enabled

results.description: The GraphQL error response includes an automatic field suggestion: it reveals the correct field name 'title' when the client queried 'titel'. This discloses schema-level information (available field names) which is a form of information disclosure often referred to as a field_suggestions vulnerability. While this does not directly execute code or leak sensitive data, it aids an attacker in enumerating the GraphQL schema and crafting targeted queries, increasing the attack surface. Recommended mitigations include disabling or sanitizing suggestion text in error messages, returning generic validation errors, and limiting error details in responses to unauthenticated or low-privilege clients.

llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error response includes an automatic field suggestion: it reveals the correct field name 'title' when the client queried 'titel'. This discloses schema-level information (available field names) which is a form of information disclosure often referred to as a field_suggestions vulnerability. While this does not directly execute code or leak sensitive data, it aids an attacker in enumerating the GraphQL schema and crafting targeted queries, increasing the attack surface. Recommended mitigations include disabling or sanitizing suggestion text in error messages, returning generic validation errors, and limiting error details in responses to unauthenticated or low-privilege clients.
